awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:  Modeling hominin variability in Australopithecus africanus
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the fundamental goals of anthropological research is to understand humanity's biological origins and evolution, for which the hominin fossil record is a primary source of data. However, it is difficult to determine, for a given time period and location, whether the relatively limited and fragmentary hominin fossils represent one or multiple species. Such is the case for South African fossils attributed to the species Australopithecus africanus. The variability in this assemblage of fossils has been proposed to represent more than one species, but there is little agreement about how to sort the various fossils. Determining species designations for this assemblage is important because it affects interpretations of A. africanus as a direct ancestor of our own genus Homo and therefore our understanding of how and where the genus Homo evolved. By incorporating methods from systematic biology and developing new statistical methods, this research will provide a necessary framework to define hominin fossil species and address diversity in hominin evolution. This project will also support training and mentoring of students, including from groups underrepresented in STEM fields, science outreach to high school students, and scan data that will be made available through Morphosource. 

The recognition of species in the fossil record is of critical importance to understanding hominin evolution and diversity. A vast literature exists on species concepts, but process-based definitions cannot be easily applied to fossil species. Accordingly, levels of variation within purported hypodigms have typically been used to delineate hominin species, but such approaches rest on the problematic assumption that these parameters are comparable in extinct and extant species. Elsewhere in biology, methods have been developed that use the structure of variance within a sample to detect the presence of discrete species. Despite continued controversy over hominin species delineation, these methods have yet to be employed in anthropology. Australopithecus africanus exemplifies this problem. Resolving its alpha taxonomy is critically important to interpreting human evolution, but it remains a contentious issue. The possibility that A. africanus subsumes two or more species has significant implications for the interpretation of the hominin phylogeny and the evolution of the genus Homo. The goal of this research is to quantitatively model species variation in extant primates and fossil hominins in order to re-evaluate the taxonomic heterogeneity of the A. africanus assemblage. This will be accomplished by using phylogenetic comparative methods to estimate an appropriate null hypothesis model of hominin variability. Data will be collected from 3D surfaces of extant primate and fossil hominin teeth using landmarks, semi-landmarks, and GIS-based approaches. The data from this study will provide a detailed model of hominin variability using both mixture models and matrix correlation analyses.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding humanity’s biological origins hinges on the ability to recognize species in the fossil record and to reconstruct their evolutionary relationships. However, the hominin fossils historically subsumed under “Australopithecus africanus” have long been a source of controversy, with some researchers suggesting that several of these fossils represent a second, distinct species. The possibility that the Au. africanus assemblage subsumes two or more species has significant implications for the interpretation of hominin evolution and the emergence of the genus Homo.  

 

The central goal of this research was to build a better of understanding hominin evolution and diversity by re-assessing the taxonomic heterogenetiy of the Au. africanus fossil assemblage, and to re-evaluate its relationship to other hominin taxa. The aims of this research grant were encompassed within the co-PI’s dissertation thesis, which was submitted in fulfillment of co-PI Mongle’s doctoral degree (awarded August 2019). 

 

Accomplishing this broader research goal was predicated on three specific aims: 1) developing a better understanding of the sources and structure of morphological variation in molar teeth; 2) establishing a well defined phylogenetic context; and develop statistical models to better parse variation in the hominin fossil record. 

 

Aim 1: In the first instance, this research has demonstrated a strong correspondence between macroevolutionary rates of molar evolution evolution and phenotypic variation at the population level (Mongle et al., 2022). This provides a link between different scales of biological variation and suggests that developmental processes may play a role in maintaining proportionality between genetic variation and evolutionary divergence over macroevolutionary time. Moreover, we suggest that that early stages of speciation in the fossil record could be captured by understanding the structure of variation in M3 morphology between species, while distinct distributions of M1 morphology could provide evidence of deeper evolutionary divergence. 

Aim 2: Australopithecus africanus has long been unstable in phylogenetic analyses. However, in order to fully evaluate the sources of this instability, we first had to undertake a comprehensive revision of the character data and hypodigm compositions used in previous hominin phylogenetic analyses. In addition, we have expanded this analysis to accommodate recent palaeontological discoveries. We demonstrate that the addition of new craniodental data markedly strengthens the support for the placement of Ardipithecus ramidus as a basal hominin (Mongle et al., 2019). The data from this research objective was publically archived, and is available for download on MorphoBank (http://dx.doi.org/10.7934/P3151).

Aim 3: Moving forward, we will use the large comparative sample collected during the course of this project, and build on the results of Aim 1 and Aim 2 to inform our models of inter- and intraspecific variation in the Au. africanus fossil assemblage. Development of these multivariate models is ongoing. 

To date, reseach conducted as part of this project has contributed to four peer-reviewed publications, with further papers in development. Eight undergraduate students were recruited to assist with data collection and scan processing phases of this project. Six of these students went on to present their research findings at the Stony Brook Undergraduate Research Symposium, and in doing so, gained experience following the scientific method, running statistical analyses, and preparing a scientific presentation. Notably, one of these students also presented her work to Kenya’s National Board for Science, Technology, and Innovation. In addition, an NSF REU student was mentored in conducting a research project using the updated hominin character matrix that was generated from this research. This student went on to pursue a PhD in Biological Anthropology.
